Tel.: +91 9864031987. Graphical abstract Rhodamine B dye in water was oxidized under ambient conditions with commercial MnO2, NiO and ZnO in a batch reactor with pH, reaction time, dye concentration, catalyst loading, and temperature as the experimental variables. Acid-activated MnO2 could achieve 100% Rhodamine B oxidation at a concentration of 1.0mg/L with a catalyst loading of 2.5g/L. The catalysts could be recovered and reused. Various catalysts have been utilized for wet oxidation of organic compounds in water. Rhodamine B is a cationic xanthene dye, used in a large number of industries and is considered as an undesirable chemical in water. In the present work, commercially available metal oxides, MnO2, NiO and ZnO, and those activated by treating with 1.0N H2SO4 were used to oxidize the dye in water to innocuous compounds. The catalysts were characterized with FTIR, XRD, SEM, cation exchange capacity and BET surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution measurements. Oxidation was carried out in a batch reactor at ambient temperature and pressure under different conditions of pH, reaction time, dye concentration, catalyst loading, and temperature. Acid-activated MnO2 was the best catalyst with almost 100% Rhodamine B oxidation (dye 1.0mg/L, catalyst loading 2.5g/L). The catalysts could be recovered and reused. Oxidation followed first order kinetics and a reaction mechanism was proposed based on analysis of the products. Keywords Dye oxidation Rhodamine B MnO2 NiO ZnO 1 Introduction Textile and dyeing industries discharge effluents containing synthetic dyes and pigments. Some other industries, viz., food, pharmaceutical, cosmetics, biological imaging, liquid crystal manufacturing, etc., also yield various quantities of coloured effluents [1]. Most of the dyes are aesthetically undesirable in drinking water and are also environmentally hazardous, some of the dyes being recognized as carcinogenic [2]. The dyes interfere with properties of water and inhibit sunlight penetration into streams and other water bodies affecting the natural disinfection process and they reduce photosynthesis in underwater plants [3]. Some dyes are harmful to aquatic life even in trace concentration, and are toxic to microorganisms in the biological water treatment processes and also to food chain organisms [4,5]. It is therefore necessary to destroy the dyes in water before they become detrimental to the environment, more particularly to aquatic life. Different methods are in use for oxidation of the dyes in wastewater. A few of these are photocatalysis [6,7], oxidation with H2O2 [8], ultrasonic irradiation [9] and catalytic ozonation [10], Recent interests are in advanced oxidation processes (AOP) like Fenton and photo-Fenton processes [11], adsorption, coagulation, electrocoagulation, and combination of these techniques. Wet air oxidation (WAO) has emerged as one of the most acceptable and easy techniques for oxidation of organic pollutants. In WAO processes, the generation of active oxygen species, such as hydroxyl radicals, takes place at high temperatures and pressures. This process has strong capacities for breaking down large organic molecules to simpler, easily treatable molecules before they are released into the environment [12]. Compared to conventional wet-air oxidation, catalytic wet-air oxidation (CWAO) requires lower energy and can be carried out under less drastic conditions. In presence of a catalyst, oxidation takes place rapidly and conversion of large dye molecules to harmless products could be achieved without much difficulty [13]. Rhodamine B is a cationic xanthene dye widely used in the printing, textile, and photographic industries [14]. It is also used in foodstuff and is a well-known water tracer fluorescent dye [15]. The dye is known, however, to cause irritation of the skin, eyes and the respiratory tract. The dye is also known to possess carcinogenicity, reproductive and developmental toxicity, neurotoxicity and chronic toxicity towards humans and animals [16]. It is therefore important that this dye does not foul natural water resources. Rhodamine B dissociates into cations in water and in the present work, three commercially available transition metal oxides, MnO2, NiO and ZnO and their acid-activated forms were used to oxidize Rhodamine B cations to harmless components. The oxidation was carried out at ambient temperature and pressure with reaction time, catalyst load, dye concentration, and pH of the medium as the process variables. The oxides were chosen on the basis of different crystallinity and surface area. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals The basic catalytic materials in this work were MnO2 (BDH Chemical division), NiO (Merck Mumbai), ZnO (Oster pharmaceutical), H2SO4 (Merck Mumbai), Rhodamine B (Merck Mumbai). All chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of acid-activated catalysts The acid-activated catalysts were prepared by treating the metal oxides with 1.0N H2SO4. 15g of the material was activated with 100mL acid (H2SO4) for 4h at room temperature in a batch reactor. The material was separated by filtration and was washed with distilled water till the washings were neutral. The material was dried at 373K in an air oven for 5h and was preserved. Altogether six catalysts were tested in this work: (i) raw MnO2 (C1), (ii) acid-activated MnO2 (C2), (iii) raw NiO (C3), (iv) acid-activated NiO (C4), (v) raw ZnO (C5), and (vi) acid-activated ZnO (C6). 2.3 Preparation of stock dye solution A stock solution of the dye, Rhodamine B of concentration 1000mg/L was used to prepare the experimental dye solutions by dilution with double distilled water. Rhodamine B is a basic dye of the structure shown in Fig. 1 . 2.4 Characterization of the catalysts The catalytic materials were characterized by measuring (i) the crystallinity of the phases by XRD (Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a scintillation counter) (ii) the surface functional groups by FT-IR measurements (Perkin-Elmer Spectrum RXI, range 4000–450cm−1) using KBr self-supported pellet technique, (iii) the surface topography by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (JEOL JSM-6360), (iv) the cation exchange capacity (CEC) by copper bisethylenediamine complex method [17] and (v) the surface area and pore volume by BET adsorption isotherms (Micromeritics Tristar Surface Area and Porosity Analyzer). 2.5 Experimental procedure for wet oxidation of the dye The catalytic oxidation was carried out in a water bath shaker (NSW, New Delhi, India) with 20mL of Rhodamine B in capped 50mL Erlenmeyer flasks. The pH of the reactant solution was adjusted by adding a few drops of 0.1N HNO3 or 0.1N NaOH. After a reaction run was completed, the mixture was centrifuged (Remi Research Centrifuge, R24) and the unconverted reactant was estimated in the supernatant layer spectrophotometrically (Hitachi UV-visible U3210). The products of the reaction were analyzed with GC–MS (Perkin Elmer Clarus 600C) and FT-IR measurements. Reduction in the COD load of the reaction mixture was monitored by the dichromate reflux method [18]. In this method, 10ml of the reaction mixture was mixed with 20ml of 0.25M K2Cr2O7 solution, 30ml conc. H2SO4 and a pinch of silver sulphate. The mixture was refluxed for 2h, cooled to room temperature, 80ml of distilled water was added and was titrated with 0.1M ferrous-ammonium sulphate (FAS) solution using ferroin indicator. The whole procedure was repeated with a blank taking 10ml of distilled water in place of the reaction mixture. COD was computed from the formula: COD ( mg / L ) = ( B − S ) × M × 8000 V where B, volume of FAS used for Blank titration, S, volume of FAS used for titration of the reaction mixture, M, molarity of FAS, V, volume of the reaction mixture taken. The COD removal is calculated by the formula % COD removal = ( COD o − COD t ) × 100 COD o COD o , COD of the reaction mixture at t =0 (i.e. before commencement of oxidation); COD t , COD of the reaction mixture at t = t (i.e. after oxidation proceeded for time, t). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 Cation exchange capacity The CECs of raw and acid-activated MnO2, NiO and ZnO are given in Table 1 . These values show that acid-activation positively influenced the CEC of all three oxides although the influence was less in case of MnO2. The CEC of MnO2 increased by ∼1.2 times while those of NiO and ZnO increased by 2.5 and almost 3 times. The CEC is normally attributed to structural defects and broken bonds on the material surface and is also assigned to structural hydroxyl transfers [17] and acid-activation was likely to affect the structural defects. 3.1.2 FT-IR study The FT-IR measurements (Fig. 2 ) confirmed the presence of MO linkages even after acid activation. MO steretching bands of 534, 580 and 754cm−1 in raw MnO2 shifted to 524, 570 and 748cm−1 after acid activation [19]. The NiO bands appearing at 576 and, 512cm−1 [20] shifted to 562 and 498cm−1 in acid-activated NiO. Similar shift was also observed in case of ZnO with the bands at 516, 610, 708cm−1 of raw ZnO [21] shifting to 510, 604, 704cm−1 in acid-activated ZnO. In all the cases, the intensities of the bands changed after acid-activation. The bands in the ranges of 3300–3500cm−1 and 1100–1600cm−1 were attributed, respectively, to MOH stretching and bending vibrations [19]. The OH stretching band occurred at 3402 and 3338cm−1 (MnO2), at 3440 and 3432cm−1 (NiO) and at 3402 and 3340cm−1 (ZnO), respectively, for the raw and the acid-activated materials. Similarly, the bands at 1590 and 1558cm−1 (MnO2), 1596 and 1590cm−1 (NiO), 1508 and 1504cm−1 (ZnO) are assigned to OH bending vibrations of the raw and the acid-activated materials, respectively. The OH bands might be due to irreversible adsorption of moisture on the surface of the oxides. However, the IR measurements showed no new bands on the surface of the oxides after acid treatment indicating that the acid had not interacted chemically with the metal oxides. 3.1.3 XRD measurements The XRD spectra of raw and acid-activated oxides are shown in Fig. 3 . The raw MnO2 showed a few prominent peaks at 2θ of 12.58°, 25.27°, 38.10°, 56.38°, 68.80° which shifted to 12.49°, 24.86°, 37.85°, 56.24°, 66.21° after acid-activation. The reflections could be assigned to the tetragonal symmetry of MnO2 molecule and can be indexed as (110), (200), (211), (002) and (600) Bragg reflctions with d spacings of 7.03, 3.52, 2.36, 1.63, 1.36Å for rawMnO2 and 7.08, 3.58, 2.38, 1.63, 1.40Å for acid-activated MnO2 [22]. NiO exhibited prominent XRD bands at 2θ values of 37.30°, 43.36°, 62.92°, 75.50°, 79.51°, shifting after acid-activationd to 37.24°, 43.28°, 62.87°, 75.40°, 79.40°. These reflections can again be assigned to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222) Bragg lines with d spacings of 2.40, 2.08, 1.47, 1.25, 1.20Å for raw NiO and 2.41, 2.09, 1.48, 1.26, 1.21Å for acid-activated NiO. Cindrella et al. [23] have found similar reflection angles and planes of symmetry for NiO. ZnO had major XRD bands at 2θ of 31.76°, 36.26°, 38.71°, 47.60°, 56.66°, 62.83°, 67.93°, 73.03°, 77.55° for the raw sample and at 31.67°, 36.19°, 38.46°, 47.44°, 56.50°, 62.77°, 67.81°, 72.84°, 77.15° for the acid-activated sample. These reflactions can be indexed as those due to hexagonal wurtzite ZnO and assigned to (100), (002), (101), (102), (110), (103), (112), (004) and (202) Braggs lines with ‘d’ of 2.81, 2.47, 2.32, 1.90, 1.62, 1.47, 1.37, 1.29, 1.23Å for raw ZnO and 2.83, 2.48, 2.34, 1.92, 1.63, 1.48, 1.38, 1.30 and 1.24Å for the acid-activated ZnO. These assignments are similar to those made by Wang et al. [24] for powder XRD of ZnO. In all the three cases, acid-activation shifted the reflactions slightly to lower angle (2θ) indicating lattice expansion to some extent, which might increase the surface area of the catalysts and therfore, the activity of the catalysts [25]. 3.1.4 Surface topography SEM micrographs (Fig. 4 ) show that the sizes of the particles both before and after acid-activation are in the order of NiO<ZnO<MnO2. The surfaces of the oxides were neither uniform nor smooth. No clear changes in topography could be observed after acid treatment although it appeared that the surfaces became rough due to acid erosion. MnO2 (C1) particles were large and fluffy, and showed no particular shape. The surface was covered with some thorny small particles. There was a difference between the particles of raw MnO2 (C1) and acid treated MnO2 (C2). The particles became smaller and appeared to have lost a number of layers from the surface. The thorn-shaped particles were removed and as a whole, the particles appeared to have become more porous. NiO (C3) particles had a flaky appearance and the flakes were damaged by acid treatment. Some of the NiO flakes had a kind of powdery deposit on them after the acid action. The micrographs showed creation of new inter-particle space in the acid activated MnO2 (C4). ZnO (C5) particles were comparatively large and were dominated by long, extrudate-shaped particles. However, after treatment with acid, these particles seemed to have coalesced into bigger particles and appeared to have more crevices and steps. As H2SO4 is a highly corrosive acid, there might be some amount of etching leading to formation of new sites of adsorption as reflected in the increase in the CEC. The surface of the oxides, particularly after acid-activation, appeared to have a large number of faults and crevices, which might be the active sites for catalytic actions. 3.1.5 BET surface area The surface area, pore diameter, and pore volume of the catalysts were measured using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) technique. The material was first degassed using N2 gas at temperature 573K. The experimentally obtained surface areas, average pore diameters and pore volumes are given in Table 2 . The variations in the quantity of N2 gas adsorbed at different relative pressures yielded a linear isotherm plot (Fig. 5 ). The surface area and the total pore volume of the raw MnO2 (2.51m2/g and 0.65×10−2 cm3/g) increased several times after acid activation (161.31m2/g and 22.88×10−2 cm3/g). It was observed that the volume of the pores with diameters in the range, 3.3–3.6nm increased by 185 times after acid activation of the raw MnO2, indicating that the treatment with the acid opened up a large number of pores in this size range. The pores of diameter, 5–9nm, also exhibited an increase in volume by ∼44 times in relation to the raw oxide, but pores of diameter>9nm did not have much increase in pore volume. The overall result was that a large number of pores became available after acid treatment. The BET measurements of MnO2 did not show pores open at both ends. The surface area and the pore volume of NiO and ZnO were, respectively, 40.88m2/g and 7.95×10−2 cm3/g (raw NiO), 46.59m2/g and 8.66×10−2 cm3/g (acid-activated NiO), 8.57m2/g and 1.87×10−2 cm3/g (raw ZnO), 17.02m2/g and 6.80×10−2 cm3/g (acid-activated ZnO). In NiO, the pores of diameter 3.3–3.9nm and 5.0–7.0nm showed an increase in volume by 1.4 and 1.7 times, respectively, after acid activation and there was no significant increase in the volume of pores of other sizes. Consequently, the total pore volume of NiO increased only by 1.1 times after acid activation. In ZnO, acid treatment increased the volume of the pores of diameter, 2.0–3.0nm, by 4.3 times, those of diameter, 3.0–5.0nm, by 2.5 times and those of diameter>5.0nm by ∼1.7 times. The total pore volume increased by 3.2 times after acid activation in ZnO. Both NiO and ZnO also did not have pores open at both ends. As a whole, BET measurements revealed that the effects of acid-activation on NiO and ZnO were not as drastic as in MnO2. The effects of acid activation on volume of pores of different sizes are shown in Fig. 6 . Qu et al. [26] have found BET surface area of 31.78–45.20m2/g for the electrolytic MnO2, values almost 15 times as large as those of commercial MnO2 found in this work, but much less than that of the acid-activated MnO2. Electrochemically synthesized, finely dispersed NiO film was shown to have a surface area of 86–153m2/g [27], a much larger value than the one obtained for commercial NiO in this work. Reddy et al. [28] showed the surface area of ZnO nano particles to be between 8.28 and 43.76m2/g depending on temperature, these are also much higher than those obtained in this work for commercial ZnO. Interestingly, the acid-activated ZnO has a surface area comparable to that of ZnO nano particles indicating considerable reduction in the size of ZnO particles after acid treatment. The same conclusion is also valid for NiO. In case of MnO2, the acid activation had a very pronounced effect on size reduction of the particles resulting in huge increase in surface area and pore volume. 3.2 Wet oxidation of Rhodamine B 3.2.1 Effects of pH At constant dye concentration (10.0mg/L) and catalyst load (2.5g/L), the oxidation of Rhodamine B was carried out over the pH range of 2.0–12.0 at ambient temperature (303K) for 5h. The conversion of the dye was nearly constant at pH 2.0–6.0 and the conversion increased continuously from pH 6.0 to 12.0. The trends in percentage conversion with pH are shown in Fig. 7 . Oxidative conversion of the dye was 10.35%, 96.32%, 4.95%, 36.85%, 27.31%, 55.67% for the catalysts C1, C2, C3, C4, C5 and C6 at pH 2.0 and was 26.34%, 100.00%, 10.45%, 53.46%, 38.67%, 69.49% for the same catalysts, respectively, at pH 12.0. The conversion was maximum in the basic medium and minimum in the acidic medium. The oxidation was obviously favoured by the presence of hydroxyl radicals in the basic medium. It has been shown before that in an alkaline medium, the catalyst surface remains covered with a layer of hydroxyl ions [29] that initiate decomposition of the dye. Trends similar to those in the present work were observed by Jain et al. [30] for Rhodamine B oxidation over TiO2 catalyst also at 303K. 3.2.2 Kinetics of Rhodamine B oxidation This set of reactions was carried out with fixed dye concentration (1.0mg/L) and catalyst load (2.5g/L) but varying the reaction time from 15 to 300min at ambient temperature (303K) and pH 6.7. The reactions achieved equilibrium at around 240min and the conversions were 12.7–30.2% (C1, raw MnO2), 78.7–99.9% (C2, acid-activated MnO2), 1.8–11.5% (C3, raw NiO), 13.7–47.5% (C4, acid-activated NiO), 20.0–38.9% (C5, raw ZnO), 41.6–75.0% (C6, acid-activated ZnO) between 15min and the equilibrium time. The conversion was the least with the raw NiO although the acid-activated catalysts showed remarkable improvement in each case. The increase in total conversion of the dye with reaction time for all the six catalysts is shown in Fig. 8 . For both NiO and ZnO, acid treatment increased Rhodamine B oxidation almost by the same extent despite raw ZnO achieving a much higher conversion compared to raw NiO. The oxidation was most remarkable for the acid-activated MnO2 (C2), which could oxidize 78.7% of the dye just in 15min and 99.9% at equilibrium. These results are in perfect agreement with the large increase in surface area observed in acid-activated MnO2 and in particular, the manifold increase in the volumes of the pores in the diameter ranges of 3.3–3.6nm and 5.0–9.0nm. The size of Rhodamine B molecules being 1.8nm [31,32], large number of pores of appropriate size is available in acid-activated MnO2 for the dye molecules and their subsequent conversion. The results of Rhodamine B oxidation with raw and acid-activated MnO2 compare very favourably with some other newly developed catalytic materials. Saleh et al. [33] achieved 92% Rhodamine B decomposition with multi-walled carbon nanotube/tungsten oxide catalyst and 49% with only tungsten oxide nano powder as the catalyst at pH 5.5. Abdel-Messih et al. [34] obtained ∼92% and 72% degradation of the dye in 3h with TiSn10 and pure titania as the catalysts under UV-irradiation and 32% and 22% in dark. Wang et al. [24] obtained a conversion of 39.1% of Rhodamine B with ZnO nano powder as the catalyst at 25.0±0.2°C. Application of the pseudo-first order kinetics to Rhodamine B oxidation by plotting log C t versus time on the basis of the equation: (1) log C t = log C 0 − k 2.303 t is shown in Fig. 9 . The plots are linear (regression coefficient, R =0.92–0.99) for all the catalysts and the first order rate coefficient obtained from these plots are 1.15×10−3, 0.46×10−3, 0.92×10−3 min−1, respectively, for the raw metal oxides (C1, C3, C5) and 3.22×10−3, 0.92×10−3 and 2.99×10−3 min−1 for the acid-activated oxides (C2, C4, C6). The rate coefficient increased after acid treatment by 2.00–3.25 times indicating a faster degradation of the dye. In an earlier work, Zaman et al. [35] have found that degradation of Rhodamine B and Methylene Blue on CuO nanostructures at room temperature also followed first order kinetics. 3.2.3 Effects of dye concentration and catalyst loading Rhodamine B conversion at ambient temperature (303K) and pH (6.7) carried out over a constant catalyst loading of 2.5g/L for 5h, decreased with increase in concentration of the dye (1, 10, 50, 100mg/L) as shown in Table 3 . The increasing density of dye molecules compared to the fixed number of active sites results in a decrease in dye degradation [36,37]. Cui et al. [36] found similar decrease in Rhodamine B (5–25mg/L) degradation over a photocatalyst (Cd1−x Zn x S/K2Ti4O9). The optimum catalyst loading was determined by carrying out the oxidation of the dye with four different catalyst loadings of 0.5, 2.5, 5 and 7.5g/L (dye concentration 1.0mg/L, pH 6.7, temperature 303K, reaction time 5h). The results were shown in Fig. 10 . The catalyst load did not have much influence on the conversions. Rhodamine B oxidation with the raw oxides MnO2, NiO and ZnO increased from 23.2% to 30.2%, 5.6% to 11.5% and 30.3% to 38.9% for the catalyst loading in the range of 0.5–2.5g/L. The acid-activated MnO2, NiO and ZnO catalysts showed similar increase in oxidation of Rhodamine B from 93.7% to 99.9%, 40.3% to 47.5% and 66.5% to 75.0% with the catalyst loading in the range of 0.5–2.5g/L. The increases are in agreement with the surface areas of the catalysts indicating a clear relation between surface area and catalytic activity. A small loading of 0.5g/L of the acid-activated MnO2 could decompose more than 93% of the dye. Mishra et al. [38] obtained 92.9% degradation of Rhodamine B in a sono-photocatalytic process using TiO2 (2g/L). However, if the process was carried out simply with TiO2 (2g/L) and H2O2 (0.5g/L) at 30±5°C, the degradation was 81.2%. The results obtained with acid-activated MnO2 in the present work are even better than these and there was also no need of using an oxidizing agent like H2O2. 3.2.4 Effect of temperature Rhodamine B (10.0mg/L) oxidation (reaction time 5h, pH 6.7) with a fixed catalyst load (2.5g/L) in the temperature range of 298–313K showed that the oxidative destruction of the dye cations improved if the temperature was increased (Table 4 ). The dye molecules become more mobile at higher temperature and can reach the catalyst surface easily to undergo transformation making the process transport dependent at higher temperature. Similar trend was found by Yuan et al. [39] for oxidation of Safranin T over macroporous ZnO/MoO3/SiO2 hybrid catalyst in the temperature range of 293–308K. 3.3 COD measurements After Rhodamine B oxidation was carried out over the raw metal oxides (C1, C3 and C5) at room temperature for 4h, the COD load of the reaction mixture decreased by 19.2% for C1, 4.6% for C3 and 22.4% for C5. The COD reduction for the acid treated catalysts (C2, C4 and C6) under identical conditions was 87.3% for C2, 35.7% for C4 and 63.6% for C6 catalysts. The large reduction in COD indicated oxidation of the dye to simpler organic compounds and considerable mineralization. Li et al. observed ∼85 to 90% COD reduction in oxidation of Rhodamine B using several modified TiO2 catalysts [29]. 3.4 Recovery and reuse of the catalysts The catalysts after use were separated by centrifugation and were washed thoroughly with water to remove the dye molecules bound on the catalyst surface. Each used catalyst was taken with 100mL water in an Erlenmeyer flask and was agitated vigorously in a water bath shaker for 4h. The catalyst was separated by centrifugation again and dried in an air oven at ∼393K. This material was reused for catalytic oxidation of the dye. It was found that even after six runs of the oxidation reaction, the efficiency of the catalysts for Rhodamine B oxidation decreased by less than 3.0% only. 3.5 Mechanism of Rhodamine B degradation The products of decomposition of Rhodamine B (acid-activated MnO2 as the catalyst) were analyzed with GC–MS and FT-IR measurements. The reaction mixture was mixed with an equal volume of dichloromethane (DCM) and was agitated for 30min and allowed to settle down. 0.6μL of the DCM extract was injected to the GC–MS and the oxidation products were identified with standard mass-spectral database. The reaction mixture was found to contain products identified as phthalic acid, adipic acid, glutaric acid, 2-hydroxypropanoic acid, propane-1,2,3-triol, butane-1,3-diol, formic acid, acetic acid, and 2-dydroxy acetic acid. Most of these products are less harmful towards environment and could be further broken down to low molecular weight acids and finally to CO2 and H2O achieving complete mineralization. Natarajan et al. [40] found similar types of products in Rhodamine B oxidation over Degussa P-25 TiO2 photocatalyst with electro-spray ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS). FT-IR spectra were taken to confirm the presence or absence of some bonding groups before and after the reaction. The bands found for Rhodamine B before reaction were 3066 and 2966cm−1 (assigned to CH stretching vibrations), 1593 and 1409cm−1 (aromatic ring vibrations), 1334cm−1 (C-aryl bond vibration), 1265cm−1 (alkyl halides), 794cm−1 (CH deformation). After oxidation, two new bands at 898 and 3402cm−1 appeared and these may be assigned to the formation of NH stretching vibrations. The accompanying disappearance of the bands, 1334 and 1409cm−1, indicated total destruction of aromatic links. The FT-IR spectra before and after reaction are shown in Fig. 11 . Baldev et al. [41] found similar results for degradation of Rhodamine B over green microalgae, Coelastrella sp., at 303K. After reaction, these authors found bands at 3402 and 896cm−1 for NH stretching vibrations indicating destruction of aromatic bonds in Rhodamine B. The results from GC–MS and FT-IR could be used to conclude that Rhodamine B molecules were converted to small molecular weight organic and inorganic species which were less hazardous and finally could be completely mineralized to CO2, water and other inorganic anions. The most probable oxidation pathway is shown in Scheme 1 . It is likely that Rhodamine B is first converted to benzoic acid and a complex radical form of xanthenylidene, which could be converted to other simpler organic acids and inorganic compounds. 4 Conclusions From the results, it could be concluded that Rhodamine B cations in water could be oxidized by acid-activated oxide catalysts. Among the catalysts, acid-activated MnO2 had the best catalytic activity. The results are in complete conformity with the physico-chemical characteristics of the catalysts such as BET surface area. The activities of the catalysts are in the order of C2>C6>C4>C5>C1>C3. The kinetics of the reaction followed first order rate equation. The final products of the dye were less harmful for the environment and also for the aquatic system. The oxide catalysts are cheap, easily available and do not require much initial treatments except acid-activation. These materials have very good potential for oxidizing hazardous organic cationic such as those Rhodamine B in water to environmentally harmless products. coredata.dc:description: Various catalysts have been utilized for wet oxidation of organic compounds in water. Rhodamine B is a cationic xanthene dye, used in a large number of industries and is considered as an undesirable chemical in water. In the present work, commercially available metal oxides, MnO2, NiO and ZnO, and those activated by treating with 1.0N H2SO4 were used to oxidize the dye in water to innocuous compounds. The catalysts were characterized with FTIR, XRD, SEM, cation exchange capacity and BET surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution measurements. Oxidation was carried out in a batch reactor at ambient temperature and pressure under different conditions of pH, reaction time, dye concentration, catalyst loading, and temperature. Acid-activated MnO2 was the best catalyst with almost 100% Rhodamine B oxidation (dye 1.0mg/L, catalyst loading 2.5g/L). The catalysts could be recovered and reused. Oxidation followed first order kinetics and a reaction mechanism was proposed based on analysis of the products.
coredata.dc:title: Oxidation of Rhodamine B in aqueous medium in ambient conditions with raw and acid-activated MnO2, NiO, ZnO as catalysts
